verses.text: Do not rely on your wealth, and do not say, 'I have enough.'
verses.comment: The warning here recalls how trusting in riches leads people away from dependence on God. See also Jesus’ teaching in Matthew 6:24 about serving God rather than wealth.

verses.text: Do not follow your strength to walk in the desires of your heart.
verses.comment: Here, the text warns against letting personal desire override obedience to God's law, a principle reflected throughout Scripture.

verses.text: Do not say, 'Who can overpower me?' For the Lord will surely punish you.
verses.comment: Boasting in one's own power ignores the sovereignty of God, echoing the teaching against pride in James 4:6.

verses.text: Do not say, 'I have sinned, and nothing bad happened to me,' for the Lord is patient.
verses.comment: God’s patience should not be mistaken for indifference to sin. This is a key theme in both Old and New Testament teachings on repentance and judgment.

verses.text: Do not be so confident in forgiveness that you keep adding sin upon sin.
verses.comment: This verse cautions against presuming on God’s mercy, a theme also addressed by Paul regarding grace—not a license to sin.

verses.text: Do not say, 'His mercy is great, He will forgive the abundance of my sins.' For both mercy and wrath come from Him, and His anger rests on sinners.
verses.comment: The balance of mercy and justice in God’s character is emphasized here. Spiritual interpretation suggests true repentance and conversion is essential.

verses.text: Do not delay to turn to the Lord, and do not put off repentance from day to day.
verses.comment: Prompt repentance is urged, reflecting the urgency seen in Christ’s call to conversion. There is a spiritual sense here of being always ready and watchful.

verses.text: For suddenly the wrath of the Lord will come forth, and in the time of vengeance you will be destroyed.
verses.comment: God’s judgment may come when least expected. This echoes Jesus’ warnings about sudden judgment and the need for readiness.

verses.text: Do not be swayed by worthless goods, nor pursue gain at any price.
verses.comment: Clinging to material goods distorts the heart’s priorities, as Jesus teaches in His warnings against greed.

verses.text: Do not let your mouth lead you into sin, and do not say about an oath, 'It was only a mistake.'
verses.comment: This connects closely to New Testament warnings on careless speech and the commitment required for vows. There is a spiritual implication for the discipline needed in sacred promises.

verses.text: Do not be quick to speak, nor be careless with your words.
verses.comment: Wisdom literature constantly teaches restraint in speech; see also James’ emphasis on taming the tongue for the building up of the community.

verses.text: For by your words you may be destroyed, and by your speech you may be ensnared.
verses.comment: Speech has direct consequences in both Old and New Testament teaching. Christ Himself warns of accountability for every idle word.

verses.text: Listen before you speak, and be instructed before you fall ill.
verses.comment: Listening and accepting instruction is a repeated biblical principle, leading to spiritual health and avoiding error.

verses.text: In all matters be mindful, and do not be careless in what you do or say.
verses.comment: Mindfulness reflects a call to holistic holiness, watching both actions and words; see also Matt. 26:41.

verses.text: Do not be called a liar by your words or by your actions; for shame and guilt come to the double-tongued.
verses.comment: Integrity in word and deed is central to life in Christ. Spiritual interpretation sees this as an ongoing call to conversion and being made new in the truth.
